config.data: react-strings only needs the following files:

files.data: Languages, these files contain the information corresponding to each language
file: // for key autocompletion without TypeScript, the main language must be a js file

files.data: Configuration, this file will have the following structure and is used to initialize string management
file: // Import your main language for key autocompletion
// strings need only one key, others will be ignored
// direction: optional, useful for rtl languages
// import other languages as promises, use them on demand
// browser: optional, use this to get browser languages
// storage: optional, use this to preserve user preferences
// The following values are used in transitions to avoid flickering
// bgColor: optional, use CSS colors, default white
// getLocale: returns a locale after resolving storage and browser
export const { StringsProvider, useStrings, getLocale } = initStrings;

files.data: Container, this should be placed in the project or route layout
file: // locale: optional, used for single language bundle

files.data: That is all it takes to add multi-language support to your project. To get strings or arrays for each language, just use the useStrings hook inside a component
file: const { Str, Arr, language, setLanguage } = useStrings();
// this button changes the current language
// setLanguage is disabled if locale is in provider
// this returns a string with a dynamic value
